As developers, understanding how to navigate the submission workflow is crucial for creating efficient insurance solutions. Today, we’ll delve into the intricacies of building a robust policy from the ground up, setting the stage for a seamless policy lifecycle.

It's these steps that transform basic inputs into a binding insurance contract. Our journey will cover each phase, ensuring you grasp the complete picture.

slides.title: Kickstarting a New Submission
slides.originalNotes:
Submissions
In order to create a new submission, you need an account. If you are not sure how to get an account , refer to the Accounts lesson.

After you create an account and start the new submission process, relevant information can be entered via the submission wizard to present a policyholderwith a quote. You can then move forward from a quote to the binding and issuing of a policy. In this lesson, you will learn how each step looks in PolicyCenter, and what details are required to get a quote or fully bound policy.

When creating a new submission, you have the option of either creating a quick quote or a full application submission.

• Quick Quote gathers the minimal information needed to generate a quote.
• Full Application gathers a complete set of information needed to apply for a bindable quote.

We will focus on the Full Application submission in this lesson. For information about the Quick Quote submission, refer to PolicyCenter documentation

slides.title: Exploring the Submission Workflow
slides.originalNotes:
Policy submission: full application
Before examining the details of each step, let's take a look at the submission workflow process.

A full application is a complete set of information needed to issue a policy. The •completen set includes the product selection, the specific offering, basic policy information, coverables, coverages and modifiers for the specific line of business (LOB), and underwriting details related to risk analysis. After the user enters the full information, they can generate a quote for the policyholder. Ifthe quote is acceptable, the policy can be issued and bound, becoming a legal contract. To reach the Bind and Issue step in this diagram, first the quote must exist. Each of these steps will be covered in the demo. You can edit and change details about the policy ("Modify quote" bracket) any time before the Quote is created.

Multiple submissions are permitted. In the default application, no more than five submissions can be made per LOB. For example, an insuredowns several homes and wants to have a home owner's policy for each home.

slides.title: Personal Auto Submission Demo
slides.originalNotes:
Demonstration
Run through the Personal Auto demo (refer to Instructor Guide). Use Ray Newton’s account and show the students how to complete a full application and submit significant pieces of required information. Show students how to add new drivers and vehicles, and point out the requirements for the number of accidents- The following information applies to each policy demo, regardless of LOB.

Offerings: An offering allows insurers to define different product types based on existing base product definitions. Offerings can also be used for marketing
programs, which are which are targeted versions of an insurance policy intended for a specific market segment. A marketing program is intended for a particular type of business, producer or region.

Pre-Qualification: The next step in the submission process is to answer a series of pre-qualification questions. These questions are used as an early indicator to reveal if an applicant qualifies for the type of insurance being sought. Filtered questions are tied to a specific answer. During Qualification, underwriting issues may arise based on the applicant’s responses. These issues will appear in the Risk Analysis review.

Policy Info: Captures basic information about the primary named insured, the producer, policy details, and theselected underwriting company.

Underwriting: Large insurers license subsidiaries to underwrite policies on their behalf to accommodate state regulatory requirements. Many states do not allow insurers to have more than one set of rates per underwriting company. If insurers want to offer multiple sets of rates in that state, they must file each set under a separate underwriting company for that state. Underwriters may profile an account to determine its market segment to determine which underwriting company can underwrite the policy. The rates are determined for the account through this profiling method. In the example, there are three possible segments: low, medium and high- This selection influences the rating of the policy and the policy's cost More details about underwriting are available in other training lessons as well as PolicyCenter documentation.

Coverages: Coverage patterns were first mentioned with respect to the Product Model- Examples of Personal Auto ( PA) coverage include collision or liability coverages.

Modifiers: Decreases or increases premiums based on specific factors. More details on modifiers are available in the Product DesJgner discussiom Risk Analysis: This section is where any underwriting concerns appear during the submission process. Underwriters have the option to remove or maintain any issues that are blocking the issuance of a policy- Underwriting issues may appear in Risk Analysis based on pre-qualification answers.

Policy Review: The full application summary is available here.

Quote: When you select Quote, all the policy information is fed into a rating engine to calculate the premium. After the Quote returns, both Forms and Payments become available. This is in preparation for the binding an issuance of the policy

Forms: These are discussed in a later lessom

Payments: Before binding or issuing a policy, the payment screen provides an in-depth look at the different payment options, making it easy to switch between the different plans. The payment information comes from an integrated billing system. Specifics about payment configuration are available in PolicyCenter documentation or a supplemental education lesson.

Bind: Makes the policy a legal contract insuring the applicant PolicyCenter sends information to the billing system- No documents are printed after the Bind Only selection. The submission status changes to "Bound.“

Issue: When the "Issue Policy" menu item is selected, PolicyCenter sends information to the billing system and PolicyCenter sends information to the printing system to provide hard copy documents to the insured. The base application Issue Policy option also binds the policy. The resulting status is "Issued". Configured versions of PolicyCenter may require additional steps prior to binding.

PolicyCenter makes a distinction between binding and issuing a submission. Binding means that the insured and the insurer have agreed to terms and price, , and a policy is in force. If the insured has a car accident one hour after the submission is bound, the policy covers the incident even though the insured has not received oficial documentation. Issuing means that a submission may be bound, but its policy documents have not yet been issued. Perhaps the insurer needed to collect or verify additional information, , so the policy issuance occurs after the information is added is added to the policy.

slides.title: Understanding Asynchronous Quoting
slides.notes: To enable asynchronous quoting, set the AsynchronousQuotingEnabled parameter to true. It triggers when coverables exceed a threshold, enhancing performance.
slides.narration: Asynchronous quoting is a game-changer in managing complex policies. By enabling the AsynchronousQuotingEnabled parameter, PolicyCenter processes quotes in the background, enhancing user experience by freeing up the interface. This is particularly useful when dealing with a large number of coverables, ensuring smooth and efficient operations.

slides.title: Asynchronous quoting
slides.originalNotes:
Asynchronous quoting
To use asynchronous quoting, AsynchronousQuotingEnabled must be enabled, and the parameter set to true. By default, it is disabled, however, it has been enabled for training purposes.

In the base configuration, asynchronous quoting is available in the commercial lines of business and all policy transactions. Through configuration, asynchronous quoting can be modified to meet your needs and be added to other lines of business. The base configuration, PolicyCenter triggers asynchronous quoting when the number of coverables exceeds the configurable threshold of three. The table shows the coverables that trigger asynchronous quoting in the base configuration The default threshold is 30 coverables. For training purpose, the threshold for the Commercial Auto and Businessowners lines has been changed to 3 in gw/lob/common/AsyncQuoteCov erableThresholdByLine.gs.

slides.title: Asynchronous quoting flow
slides.originalNotes:
Asynchronous quoting flow
1. When you select Quote, PolicyCenter displays an alert informing you informing you that quoting will be processed in the background. To proceed, select 0K
a) PolicyCenter creates a work item for the quote and places it in a work queue for the Asynchronous Quoting work queue to process-
b) Until asynchronous quoting completes, PolicyCenter displays a message at the top of the policy transaction screens indicating that the quote is being processed.

2. The policy transaction is locked and cannot be edited- Only . Only the Back and Next buttons are available. You can view the current policy transaction and navigate to other screens to do other work.

3. When quoting completes, PolicyCenter:
a) Unlocks the policy transaction-
b) Creates an activity that the quote completed. The activity subject indicates whether the quote completed successfully or completed with warnings or errors.

4. Navigate to Desktop—My Activities, and click the activity Subject to view the activity and the associated quote. PolicyCenter displays the Quote screen for the policy transaction and the associated activity in the Activity tab. If the quote has warnings or errors, they can be viewed viewed in the Validation Results tab next to the Activity tab. More issues, such as rating or unexpected errors, will appear on the policy transaction screen. A quote with only informational messages will not have a Validation Results tab.
